name: Chicken Schnitzel
name_origin: The word 'Schnitzel' is of German origin, derived from the verb 'schnitzen', meaning 'to carve' or 'to cut'. The suffix '-el' is a diminutive, so the word literally translates to 'a little cut' or 'a slice'. While the dish originated in Austria (Wiener Schnitzel, made with veal), it was brought to Israel by Central European (Ashkenazi) immigrants. In Israel, due to the scarcity of veal, turkey and chicken became the standard proteins. It was subsequently adopted by North African Jewish communities (including Djerbans) in Israel and France, often replacing more complex traditional fried dishes due to its convenience and popularity with children.
description: Thinly pounded chicken breasts coated in seasoned breadcrumbs and fried until golden and crispy. While originally a European dish, it has become a ubiquitous staple in Israeli and North African Jewish kitchens, often served for Shabbat lunch.
cultural_context: Adopted by North African Jewish families in Israel and the diaspora, often replacing traditional fried fish or meat patties. It is typically served with couscous, mashed potatoes, or Israeli salad.
vegan_adaptation_notes: Replace chicken with tofu or seitan; use chickpea flour batter instead of eggs.

ingredients.name: Seitan cutlets or Super Firm Tofu
ingredients.notes: if using tofu, press firmly to remove liquid

ingredients.name: Seasoned breadcrumbs
ingredients.notes: ensure vegan; or plain crumbs with paprika, garlic, and salt

steps.instruction: Pound the chicken breasts with a meat mallet until they are thin, but be careful not to tear the meat.
steps.tips: Place the chicken between two sheets of plastic wrap or parchment paper before pounding to keep things clean.

steps.instruction: Prepare a dredging station with three separate plates: one with flour, one with beaten eggs, and one with seasoned breadcrumbs.
Coat each piece of chicken first in the flour (shake off excess), then dip into the egg, and finally coat thoroughly with the breadcrumbs.
Heat a generous amount of oil in a deep pan. The oil should be hot but not smoking.
steps.tips: To test the oil, drop a few breadcrumbs in; if they sizzle immediately, it is ready.

steps.instruction: Fry the schnitzels until golden brown on both sides. Drain on paper towels before serving.

name_etymology.meaning: Little slice / A cut / A carving
name_etymology.notes: Standard Germanic etymology. In the context of a Djerban cookbook, this represents the 'Israeli-zation' or 'French-ification' of the cuisine. In French-influenced North Africa, this would traditionally be called 'Escalope Panée'.

alternative_names.name: Escalope (Panée)
alternative_names.notes: The term used by Francophone North African Jews (Tunisia/Algeria/Morocco) before the adoption of the Hebrew/German term 'Schnitzel'.

alternative_names.name: Cotoletta
alternative_names.notes: Used specifically by Libyan Jews due to Italian colonization, referring to the same breaded cutlet concept.

alternative_names.name: Bani
alternative_names.notes: A localized pronunciation of the French 'pané' (breaded), often heard in Tunisian markets.

similar_dishes.name: Wiener Schnitzel
similar_dishes.similarity: The original version of the dish.
similar_dishes.key_difference: Strictly made with veal and fried in lard or butter (non-kosher preparation), whereas the Jewish version uses chicken/turkey and oil.

similar_dishes.name: Maakouda
similar_dishes.similarity: A fried, breaded item often served alongside or in sandwiches.
similar_dishes.key_difference: Maakouda is a potato fritter/cake, not a whole muscle meat cutlet.

similar_dishes.name: Cotoletta alla Milanese
similar_dishes.key_difference: Usually bone-in veal chop, whereas Jewish Schnitzel is boneless pounded chicken breast.

intro_paragraph: Schnitzel comes from the German word for a little cut and was brought to Israel by European immigrants. This vegan adaptation replaces poultry with savory seitan or tofu while keeping the classic golden crust. It remains a favorite for Shabbat lunch served alongside fluffy couscous or fresh salads.

vegan_substitutions.replacement: Seitan cutlets or Super Firm Tofu
vegan_substitutions.notes: Seitan provides a chewier, meatier texture, while tofu is softer.
A mix of chickpea flour and water creates a strong binder.
